Subject: Adapting NEAT for Automatic Programming Re: [neat] Re: New paper on
 Evolution Rivaling Backprop
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=560016186; y=FM6Q03tN6nIoZIjVM8ukwmtfE1JK6iU9B9KF5Mszt_tZ6Hs
X-Yahoo-Profile: andrii_z
From: Logan Streondj <streondj@...>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi David,

I've been thinking about how to adapt or merge neural nets and code
generation, so I really like your tutorial there, as it has really
given me some ideas. I'm wondering if they make sense.

So basically the idea is that the neural-network would consist of a
variety of functions much like in your examples. Thus they would
really be a computer program, similar to flow based programming.

For instance could even do subtraction or division by having two input
dendrites on a neuron/node,  could plug in a constant if not connected
to another neuron.

then in order to convert the neural net into a computer program, could
simply flatten it layer by layer,
so assuming it progresses from left to right, then each layer would be
written down top to bottom.

This way the computer program could both be GP evolved (left to
right), and backproped, or fine tuned (right to left).

Anyways tell me what you think, and if that makes sense at all.
I am very new to machine learning so don't grasp all the concepts.

Thanks,
Logan
